Context:
Program Name: Project Management
Code: B415
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 8 months (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January, May, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,439.00
International Tuition: $18,333.00
Location: St. James Campus
Program Overview: A graduate certificate program that equips students with the knowledge and skills to manage projects and succeed in business and project management careers.
Skills gained after completion: managing project scopes, changes, innovation, goal setting, risk management, using project management tools, and adapting projects in response to issues.
Available formats: On-campus (B415) and online (B425)
Related programs: International Business Management (B411), Business Administration – Project Management (with work experience) (B156), Human Resources Management (B408)

Context: The text is about a Project Management postgraduate program offered by the School of Management at George Brown College. The program equips students with skills to apply project management practices in various industries, align projects with organizational strategic plans, and use business concepts, practices, and tools. Students will participate in a field-based course where they coordinate and execute real industry projects, gaining experience in areas like defining requirements, creating project plans, tracking budgets, coordinating meetings, monitoring progress, assessing risks, managing stakeholders, implementing management tools, preparing reports, and conducting themselves professionally. Graduates can expect to pursue careers as Junior Project Managers, Team Leaders, Project Coordinators, Project Administrators, or Project Analysts. The program is recognized by the Project Management Institute (PMI) as a Global Registered Education Provider, enabling graduates to apply for PMP or CAPM certifications.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Postgraduate) B415 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
To apply for the Project Management Institute (PMI)'s Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) certification, you need one of the following:
- A secondary degree and at least 1,500 hours of project experience or 23 hours of project management education, with an additional hours exceeding the 35 hours education requirement upon completion of the B415 Project Management program. The CAPM exam consists of 150 multiple-choice questions.

To apply for the PMI's Project Management Professional (PMP) certification, you need one of the following:
- A secondary degree and at least five years of project management experience with 7,500 hours leading and directing projects and 35 hours of project management education. The PMP certification is an important industry-recognized certification for project managers.
- A four-year degree and at least three years of project management experience with 4,500 hours leading and directing projects and 35 hours of project management education. The B415 Project Management Program will assist students preparing for the PMP or CAPM exams by learning tools, techniques, and concepts directly related to questions that appear on these exams, as they draw on materials found in the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK version 6).

The text does not provide any factual information about the college or its programs offered.

Context:
The B415 program requires graduation completion of 9 mandatory courses. Here are the details of the courses in each semester and their respective prerequisites:

Semester 1:
- MGMT 4017: Organizational Behaviour, no pre-requisite
- MGMT 4066: AGILE Project Management, no pre-requisite
- MGMT 4015: Scope and Quality Management, no pre-requisite
- MGMT 4019: Risk Management, no pre-requisite
- MGMT 4085: Schedule and Cost Management, no pre-requisite
- MGMT 4057: Project Planning and Client Management, no pre-requisite

Semester 2:
- MGMT 4037: Project Management Case Studies, completion of Semester 1
- MGMT 4080: Business Acumen and Strategy Development, completion of Semester 1
- MGMT 4081: Project Management Simulation, completion of Semester 1

The graduates of this program are expected to demonstrate the following abilities: managing project scope, cost, timing, and quality; aligning projects with organizational strategic plans; identifying goals, constraints, deliverables, performance criteria, control needs, and resource requirements; implementing project management knowledge areas, processes, lifecycle phases, concepts, tools, and techniques; adapting projects to internal and external issues; interacting professionally with team and stakeholders; utilizing technology for communication, collaboration, information management, and decision support; applying general business concepts, practices, and tools; reflecting on their role and effectiveness as a leader and follower; and applying project management practices to various sectors of the economy.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Postgraduate) B415 | George Brown College2024.txt
